title: WebSocket writePump exit on write failure doesn't actively remove client -- relies on slow-client detection
description: In backend/internal/ws/broadcast.go, when writePump() encounters a write error (connection dead), it returns and defers conn.Close(). However, it does NOT call b.RemoveClient(c). The client remains in b.clients map. Recovery happens via a different path: the next broadcast() call finds the client's send channel full (since writePump is no longer draining it), hits the default branch, and calls b.RemoveClient(c) with a log message. In the worst case (low-traffic server), this means a dead client could remain in the map for up to snapshotInterval (default 5 seconds). During this window, each broadcast attempt to the dead client wastes a channel send. Fix: have writePump call b.RemoveClient(c) directly before returning, similar to how net/http's server handles connection cleanup.

title: Prefix-match model context windows in config
description:
Context window resolution is inconsistent across sources and requires exact model names in config.yaml. New model variants (date suffixes, preview tags) silently fall back to the 200k default. The frontend also hardcodes 200K and draws a single shared finish line regardless of per-session context windows.

## Part 1: Backend — Prefix matching for model context windows

### Current state
- Claude: no dynamic reporting, exact model name lookup in config
- Codex: dynamic reporting from events (works well), exact fallback
- Gemini: hardcoded Go switch (geminiContextWindow()) + exact config fallback
- config.yaml has ~15 exact entries that grow with every model release

### Proposed: prefix matching + delete hardcoded switch

Resolution chain (first match wins):
1. Source-reported (update.MaxContextTokens) — Codex already does this
2. Exact model name in config
3. Longest prefix match in config (NEW)
4. Global default in config
5. Hardcoded 200000

Config entries ending with * become prefix patterns, longest wins:
  claude-*: 200000
  gemini-2.5-*: 1048576
  gemini-2.0-*: 1048576
  gemini-3-*: 1000000
  gemini-1.5-pro*: 2097152
  gemini-1.5-flash*: 1048576
  gpt-4.1: 1047576  (exact override still works)
  default: 200000

Collapses ~15 entries to ~8, auto-covers future model variants.

### Files to change
- backend/internal/config/config.go — MaxContextTokens() tries exact then longest-prefix
- backend/internal/monitor/gemini_source.go — delete geminiContextWindow(), rely on config
- config.yaml + config.example.yaml — convert to prefix patterns
- Add tests for prefix matching logic

---

## Part 2: Frontend — Per-model finish lines (absolute token scale)

### Current state
- RaceCanvas.js:387 passes hardcoded 200000 to Track.draw()
- Track draws ONE shared finish line at bounds.x + bounds.width
- Car X position = contextUtilization (0–1), hiding real scale differences
- Token markers are fixed at 50K/100K/150K

### Proposed: absolute token scale with per-lane finish lines

Switch X-axis from utilization (0–1) to absolute tokens (0 to globalMax):
- globalMaxTokens = max of all active sessions' maxContextTokens
- Car X position = tokensUsed / globalMaxTokens (NOT contextUtilization)
- Each lane gets its own finish line at carMaxTokens / globalMaxTokens
- A 200K session at capacity appears at 20% of track width when a 1M session is racing
- Token markers scale dynamically to globalMaxTokens

This makes context window differences immediately visible — you can SEE that a Gemini session has 5x the runway of a Claude session.

### Changes required

**Track.js:**
- draw() receives per-lane maxTokens array (or a globalMax + per-session max), not a single global
- _drawFinishLine() → _drawLaneFinishLines() — draw per-lane finish markers at different X positions
- _drawTokenMarkers() — scale markers to globalMaxTokens dynamically
- getPositionX() — accept raw tokens + globalMax instead of utilization

**RaceCanvas.js:**
- Compute globalMaxTokens from all active sessions
- Pass tokensUsed and maxContextTokens per-racer instead of contextUtilization
- Update draw calls for track, pit, and parking lot zones

**Racer.js:**
- On-car metrics label (lines 1149-1221): already shows tokens/max, no major change

**Dashboard.js:**
- Leaderboard bars (lines 194-250): keep utilization-based coloring (green/amber/red thresholds)
- Consider adding absolute token count column

**main.js:**
- Detail flyout (lines 209-225): already shows tokensUsed / maxContextTokens, no change needed
close_reason: Prefix matching in config + per-lane absolute-scale finish lines

title: Incremental parse loses session slug — bash-progress phantoms leak through
description:
## Symptom
Phantom subagents appear on the dashboard (bash-progress-0, etc.) even when no Task tool subagents are running. Visible in API: `curl localhost:8080/api/sessions` shows subagents with slug matching the parent session and IDs like `bash-progress-0`.

## Root Cause
`ParseSessionJSONL()` in `jsonl.go:145` builds `result.Slug` from non-progress JSONL entries (line 209). On incremental parses (offset > 0), if the batch contains only progress entries, `result.Slug` stays empty. The slug filter at line 289:

    if entry.Slug != "" && result.Slug != "" && entry.Slug == result.Slug { return }

...short-circuits because `result.Slug == ""`, so `bash-progress-*` entries (which have toolUseID != parentToolUseID and carry the parent session's slug) pass through and create phantom subagents.

## Evidence
- All `bash-progress-*` entries have toolUseID != parentToolUseID but slug == parent session slug
- API confirmed: 2 phantom subagents with slug=elegant-noodling-thunder, id=bash-progress-0
- Reproduced live with no Task tool running

## Fix Approach
Pass the session's known slug into `ParseSessionJSONL` so incremental batches can filter self-progress:

1. Add `knownSlug string` param to `ParseSessionJSONL()` — seed `result.Slug` from it
2. Add `Slug` field to `SessionHandle` in `source.go`
3. Populate `handle.Slug` from session state in `monitor.go` (where KnownSubagentParents is populated)
4. Pass `handle.Slug` through `ClaudeSource.Parse()` to the parser
5. Update all `ParseSessionJSONL` call sites (tests + production)

The previously merged fix (a6b68fc) is correct and should be kept — it replaced the fundamentally broken `toolUseID == parentToolUseID` filter with slug-based detection. This bug is about making slug detection work across incremental parse boundaries.

## Files to Modify
- `backend/internal/monitor/jsonl.go` — add slug param, seed result.Slug
- `backend/internal/monitor/claude_source.go` — pass known slug
- `backend/internal/monitor/source.go` — add Slug to SessionHandle
- `backend/internal/monitor/monitor.go` — populate handle.Slug from state
- `backend/internal/monitor/jsonl_test.go` — update call signatures
- `backend/internal/monitor/subagent_test.go` — update call signatures, add incremental slug test

## Verification
1. `go test ./internal/monitor/` passes
2. No phantom subagents in `curl localhost:8080/api/sessions` when no Task tool is active
3. Real Task tool subagents still appear as hamsters on dashboard
close_reason: Fixed: added knownSlug param to ParseSessionJSONL so incremental batches filter self-progress. Regression test TestIncrementalBashProgressFiltered covers the bash-progress phantom case. Verified live: 0 phantom subagents after restart.

title: handleSessionEnd creates ghost sessions for unknown session IDs without adding them to store first

title: tmux-spawn: add -- separator before prompt when using --add-dir
description:
When the /tmux-spawn skill constructs the claude CLI command with --add-dir, the positional prompt argument is silently swallowed by the arg parser. The spawned session launches interactively but with no initial message.

**Reproduction:**
```bash
# Broken — claude starts with no prompt:
tmux new-window -c /path/to/worktree \
  "claude --add-dir /path/to/repo 'Your task is...'"

# Fixed — prompt is delivered:
tmux new-window -c /path/to/worktree \
  "claude --add-dir /path/to/repo -- 'Your task is...'"
```

**Root cause:** The claude CLI arg parser treats the string after --add-dir ambiguously when no -- separator is present. The positional prompt argument gets consumed as part of flag parsing rather than being recognized as the initial message.

**Fix:** In the /tmux-spawn skill template, change the spawn command from:
```
claude --add-dir '$REPO_ROOT' '<seed-prompt>'
```
to:
```
claude --add-dir '$REPO_ROOT' -- '<seed-prompt>'
```

This only affects invocations that use --add-dir. Without that flag, the bare `claude 'prompt'` form works fine.

title: Stats tests use time.Sleep for synchronization -- flaky under load
description: In backend/internal/gamification/stats_test.go, every test that sends events to the tracker via eventCh and then checks results uses time.Sleep(50ms) or time.Sleep(100ms) as the synchronization mechanism. The correct pattern is to drain the channel or use a synchronization point. Since StatsTracker.Run() processes events sequentially, one approach is to send a sentinel event and block until it's processed, or expose a Flush() method for testing that waits until the event queue is empty. All 15+ tests in this file are affected.

title: complete_3_no_errors challenge formula is semantically wrong
description: In backend/internal/gamification/challenges.go, the complete_3_no_errors challenge computes: errorFree := snap.TotalCompletions - snap.TotalErrors. This is subtraction of raw counts, not a measure of consecutive or independent error-free sessions. Example: 5 completions and 5 errors yields errorFree=0, but the user might have had 5 clean completions and 5 errors on different sessions. Conversely, 3 completions and 1 error yields 2, still blocking the goal even if the last 3 sessions were clean. The formula does not represent '3 sessions completed without errors' in any meaningful way. Fix: track error-free completion runs explicitly, or simplify to TotalCompletions >= 3 (remove the error subtraction) and rename the challenge, or accept this is an approximation and document it clearly.

title: TmuxResolver.getParentPID reads /proc/<pid>/stat -- fails silently on non-Linux systems

Since macOS is a common development platform for this tool (Claude Code runs on macOS), this affects real-world usage. Fix: use a build tag (//go:build linux) for the Linux implementation and provide a stub for other platforms, or use the 'ps' command cross-platform.

title: Data race: SetConfig/SetSources called from SIGHUP goroutine without mutex

title: matchPathOrParent stops at '/' but not drive root on Windows paths -- cross-platform issue
description: In backend/internal/session/privacy.go, matchPathOrParent() walks up the directory tree with: for p := path; p \!= "/" && p \!= "." && p \!= ""; p = filepath.Dir(p). On Linux/macOS this correctly stops at the filesystem root '/'. However, filepath.Dir() on Windows returns paths like 'C:\' for root -- the loop would never match '/' and would continue indefinitely (or until filepath.Dir() stops changing, which it does at 'C:\'). Since the binary targets Linux/macOS (monitored ~/.claude paths), this is not an active issue, but it is a latent cross-platform bug. The loop should also check p == filepath.Dir(p) as the termination condition to be correct on all platforms.

title: Session store GetAll() returns shared pointers -- mutations by callers would corrupt stored state
description: In backend/internal/session/store.go, GetAll() returns []*SessionState -- a slice of pointers to the actual stored SessionState objects. If any caller modifies a field on a returned pointer (e.g., s.Activity = session.Complete), the stored state is silently corrupted without going through UpdateAndNotify(). This bypasses all change notifications and could cause the broadcaster to send stale or incorrect data. The broadcaster calls store.GetAll() to build snapshots. If it accidentally mutates any returned state (unlikely given current code, but a serious invariant violation risk), it would corrupt the canonical store state. Fix: either return copies ([]*SessionState of cloned values) or document clearly that GetAll() returns live pointers that must not be mutated.

title: session.Activity UnmarshalJSON silently ignores unknown activity strings

title: RotateChallengesIfNeeded called on every event, including high-frequency EventUpdate

In practice the rotation check short-circuits after the comparison (identical week start), so this is cheap but not free. Fix: cache the current week start in StatsTracker and only call RotateChallengesIfNeeded when the cached value might be stale (e.g., on EventTerminal which is infrequent, or periodically via the save ticker).

title: Session sequence numbers in Broadcaster wrap around at uint64 max -- no test for rollover
description: In backend/internal/ws/broadcast.go, the seq field (uint64) is incremented on every message. At theoretical limits: 2^64 messages would take centuries at normal rates, so overflow is not a practical concern. However, the client-side reconnection logic (frontend/src/websocket.js) checks: seq !== this.lastSeq + 1. If seq wraps to 0, then lastSeq = maxUint64 and lastSeq + 1 = 0 (in JS, which uses float64 -- 2^53 is the max safe integer, so overflow would actually happen much sooner in JS than in Go). Add a note documenting this theoretical issue and ensure the server sends a snapshot (which resets lastSeq) periodically, so that even with uint64 math differences, reconnection always produces a clean baseline.

title: monitor.poll() catches panics nowhere -- a panic in any source's Discover/Parse crashes the whole server

Fix: wrap each source's Discover()/Parse() call in a function with a deferred recover(), log the panic, mark the source as failed, and continue polling. title: Bug: Phantom filter blocks all real subagent hamsters
description:
## Problem
Hamsters never appear in real mode. The phantom filter in jsonl.go:286 rejects ALL progress entries because Claude Code always emits toolUseID == parentToolUseID for every progress entry — including real Task tool subagents.

## Root Cause
The filter `if entry.ParentToolUseID != "" && entry.ToolUseID == entry.ParentToolUseID { return }` was added to reject "phantom" nested tool calls, but the premise was wrong: Claude Code has NEVER emitted progress entries where toolUseID differs from parentToolUseID. Analysis of 75+ JSONL files across the entire project history confirms diff_ids=0 in every single file.

## What the data looks like
- Self-progress entries: slug matches session slug (e.g., "elegant-noodling-thunder"), toolUseID == parentToolUseID
- Real subagent entries: slug differs from session slug (e.g., "swift-curious-hamster"), toolUseID == parentToolUseID  
- Both have the same toolUseID == parentToolUseID pattern — cannot use that field to distinguish them

## Why this is tricky
Simply removing the phantom filter reintroduces the original phantom bug (TestPhantomProgressEntriesFiltered). Need to understand:
1. What actually causes phantom subagents? Is it self-progress entries? Nested tool calls?
2. Are the existing phantom test cases realistic given the actual JSONL format?
3. What distinguishes a real Task tool subagent from a self-progress entry?

## Investigation needed
- Dump a real JSONL from a session that spawned Task tool subagents to see the actual entry format
- Compare toolUseID patterns between self-progress and Task tool progress entries
- Check if there's a field other than slug that reliably distinguishes them
- Verify the phantom test fixtures match reality

## Files
- backend/internal/monitor/jsonl.go:284-288 (phantom filter)
- backend/internal/monitor/jsonl.go:290-296 (slug filter)  
- backend/internal/monitor/subagent_test.go:778-804 (phantom test)
close_reason: Fixed: replaced phantom filter with slug-based self-progress detection. All monitor tests pass.

title: DecodeProjectPath is fragile: ambiguous for paths containing hyphens
description: In backend/internal/monitor/jsonl.go, DecodeProjectPath() reverses the encodeProjectPath() transform (slash-to-dash) by walking the filesystem. The encoding is ambiguous: a path component containing a hyphen is indistinguishable from a path separator. For example, /home/my-user/project encodes to -home-my-user-project, but so would /home/my/user-project or /home-my/user/project. The fallback (return basename) is lossy. This affects session working directory resolution for Claude sessions. GeminiSource uses SHA-256 instead (also one-way). Fix: store the original path somewhere (e.g., in the JSONL file itself or a sidecar), or use a lossless encoding like base64 or URL encoding of the path.

title: awardXP tier advancement formula has off-by-one: uses bp.Tier*xpPerTier threshold
description: In backend/internal/gamification/battlepass.go, awardXP() advances tiers with: for bp.Tier < maxTiers && bp.XP >= bp.Tier*xpPerTier { bp.Tier++ }. With xpPerTier=1000: tier 1 requires 1*1000=1000 XP to advance to tier 2, tier 2 requires 2*1000=2000 XP to advance to tier 3, etc. This is a progressive tier cost (each tier costs more than the last). The condition checks bp.XP >= bp.Tier*xpPerTier where bp.Tier is the CURRENT tier before increment. So to go from tier 1 to tier 2, you need XP >= 1000. From tier 2 to tier 3, XP >= 2000 (cumulative). This means total XP thresholds are: tier2=1000, tier3=2000, tier4=3000... tier10=9000. getProgress() computes within-tier progress as XP - (tier-1)*xpPerTier which is also progressive. Verify this is the INTENDED design (progressive cost) and document it -- the current code has no comment explaining the tier cost formula.

title: Weekly challenge TokensBurned accumulates session totals instead of deltas
description: In backend/internal/gamification/stats.go processEvent(), the EventUpdate branch does: wc.Snapshot.TokensBurned += s.TokensUsed. s.TokensUsed is the CUMULATIVE total tokens for the session lifetime, not a delta since the last update. Alternatively, capture TokensBurned at session completion from the terminal event, not on every update.
